div.p: EVENT that CAUSES HUMANS to BECOME INTENSELY SAD OR to GRIEF:grieve.

1. The most common general word for disasters is huò 禍 (ant. fú 福 "good fortune") which has no connotations of any metaphysical kind. (In OBI the character currently transcribed as huò 禍 - and closely related to 占 - refers not only to disasters as such, but particularly to disastrous omens.)
2. Zāi 災 refers to a natural disaster, typically sent down by Heaven.
3. Huàn 患 refers to any major or minor disaster, even down to minor irritations.
4. Yāng 殃 always refers to major natural disasters, often construed as causes by human misdemeanour, or by a failure to take preventive action.

5. Niè 孽 often has heavy metaphysical connotations and refers to disasters as caused by higher powers acting with an intention to harm, but there are some clear cases where the word refers to man-made trouble in MENG.
6. Nàn 難 refer to man-made disasters of every kind.
7. Jí 急 is a disastrous or highly precarious situation that has occurred suddenly and requires urgent attention.
8. Bù yú 不虞 is normally a minor disaster that was utterly unexpected.
9. Xiōng 凶, shěng 眚 and jiù 咎 are archaic metaphysical terms for misfortunes.
10. Hài 害 refers generally to harm, but in OBI the word standardly refers to harm done by supernatural powers or ancestors.
災，自然災難。難，專指使人遭受不幸的處境，特指兵難或由兵難造成的困苦。
厄，專指個人所遭受的困苦。
劫數 refers to inescapable doom in the future.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: damnum refers to a disaster one has brought upon oneself.
detrimentum is a disaster one suffers without having caused it.
iactura is a voluntary loss of someting which one chooses to suffer in order to avoid greater evils.
infortunium refers to a single misfortune as a vexatious, typically minor accident.
calamitas refers to a single tragic major incident.
infelicitas refers to a lasting state of misery, typically as the result of a lack of success.
miseria refers to a lasting state of very serious affliction of any kind.

bibl.title: 中國文化背景八千詞 Zhongguo wenhua beijing ba qian ci
Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the Other Italic Languages

note.p: Derivatives: calamitosus 'liable to damage or disaster' (Cato+); incolumis [adj.]

bibl.title: SYNONYMES FRANÇOIS, LEURS DIFFÉRENTES SIGNIFICATIONS, ET LE CHOIX QU'IL EN FAUT FAIRE Pour parler avec justesse
簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

entry.def: Xiōng 凶, shěng 眚 and jiù 咎 are archaic metaphysical terms for misfortunes.

sense.def: terrible supernaturally ordained disaster; great bad luck; major misfortune; dire consequences 百凶
calamitious, disastrous (also of harvests in certain years) 凶年

entry.def: È 厄 refers to personal disaster concerning one individual only.

sense.def: disaster (typically ordained by fate), tragic fate

bibl.title: 古代文化詞異集類辨考 Gudai wenhua ci yi ji lei bian kao

entry.def: Yāng 殃 always refers to major natural disasters, often construed as causes by human misdemeanour, or by a failure to take preventive action.
Yāng 殃 always refers to major natural disasters, often construed as causes by human misdemeanour, or by a failure to take preventive action.

sense.def: be in the danger of meeting a major disaster; suffer a major disaster

entry.def: Niè 孽 often has heavy metaphysical connotations and refers to disasters as caused by higher powers acting with an intention to harm, but there are some clear cases where the word refers to man-made trouble in MENG.

sense.def: curse, supernatural disaster MENG 4A8: generally disaster

entry.def: Hài 害 refers generally to harm, but in OBI the word standardly refers to harm done by supernatural powers or ancestors.

sense.def: regard the contextually determinate N as (potential) disaster, regard as threat

entry.def: Jí 急 is a disastrous or highly precarious situation that has occurred suddenly and requires urgent attention.

sense.def: those who are in urgent trouble

entry.def: Huàn 患 refers to any major or minor disaster, even down to minor irritations.

sense.def: disaster, misfortune; adversities; resulting trouble (from one's actions) 三患"three kinds of disaster"
present (someone N1) as a disaster to (someone N2) 患x於y
events that are bad for one; disasters

entry.def: Zāi 災 refers to a natural disaster, typically sent down by Heaven.
Zāi 災 refers to a natural disaster, typically sent down by Heaven.

sense.def: OBI 5: calamity; disaster (from Heaven/Nature; occasionally self-inflicted as in CC 9.1); the reference is sometimes to a fire
there was a disaster (at a place); there was a disaster in the form of a fire
state of distress; trouble; mental trauma
consider N as calamitous, spooky, of ill omen, ominous

entry.def: The most common general word for disasters is huò 禍 (ant. fú 福 "good fortune") which has no connotations of any metaphysical kind. (In OBI the character currently transcribed as huò 禍 - and closely related to 占 - refers not only to disasters as such, but particularly to disastrous omens.)

sense.def: disaster; disastrous fate, unhappy outcome; bad luck; sad fate
OBI 5: ominous sign, ominous event or phenomenon imbued with some disastrous supernatural significance
disastrous 禍事上門"disaster hits the family"
there is disaster, there will be disaster
regard as a disaster; recognise as disastrous
emergency; unfortunate unruly turn of events; highly unusual event 心傷國變; HANSHU: 有日蝕地震之變 There were extraordinary events likesolar eclipses and earthquakes.

entry.def: Nàn 難 refer to man-made disasters of every kind.

sense.def: trouble, problem, difficulties (from the part of the other feudal lords); the difficult point; disastrous consequences [often difficult to distinguish from DIFFICULT]
there is disaster, there is political trouble; there will be political difficulties; things will be difficult
regard as particularly troublesome, regard as very worrying
trouble from the part of N
pose difficulties, prove problematic; prove disadvantageous; be in trouble, be in dusastrous difficulty

entry.def: unpredictable, something that one has not thought about

sense.def: someonething unpredicted, a disaster that one has not thought about

entry.def: Bù yú 不虞 is normally a minor disaster that was utterly unexpected.

sense.def: disasters of any kind; disasters of all kinds
flood and fire; natural disaster in general; also figurative:social disaster
disasters of all kinds, disaster of any kind
be in dire straights; be in deep trouble
those struck by any kind of disaster or bereavement
disaster or defeat of any kind
disasters or misfortunes of any kind; a practical (possibly disastrous) problem
down on one's lucks, unfortunate, unlucky, exposed to misfortune, meeting with setbacks
BUDDH: three disasters in future life: being reborn as an animal, as a hungry, and going to hell. Compare 三途
in divination: bode ill; mean disaster; bring bad fortune; have a supernaturally disastrous influence
